body: If I type `!git add -p` it loops over the output and only stops if i press ctrl-c.

comment_data.body:
This is not a bug, it is the new behavior of bang commands: We no longer spawn the program with it's stdout connected to Nvim tty, instead we open a pipe, read output and display to the user. This is the only way the bang commands will be consistent across UIs, so programs designed to be used interactively from the terminal will no longer work from inside nvim.

There are two alternatives for bang commands that behave differently when opened from terminals:
- Invoke it from a shell(either from a different terminal or with ctrl+z)
- Use the fugitive git plugin
@tarruda fugitive is the reason I experienced the bug. I am in the status window (:GStatus) and press p on a line to stage/unstage it.

> @tarruda fugitive is the reason I experienced the bug. I am in the status window (:GStatus) and press p on a line to stage/unstage it.

Ok, I had never used the `p` mapping, thats why I didn't experience this bug(I always use `:Gdiff` to stage changes in split buffers).

Unfortunately there's not much I can do to help, this is a consequence of Nvim's client-server architecture which can't cope with programs being spawned in the main process tty.

It seems interactive-bang commands is a popular feature(you are not the first to report this behavior), I'm starting to think it's better to find a solution to that soon.

I also think a solution for this should be looked for, if possible. It's not a big deal, specially taking into account what is given in exchange. But it will for sure annoy many people, cause it will break their habits. So, if something can be done, we should strive for it.

> I also think a solution for this should be looked for, if possible. It's not a big deal, specially taking into account what is given in exchange. But it will for sure annoy many people, cause it will break their habits. So, if something can be done, we should strive for it.

A possible solution crossed by mind: A "bang command provider", which would be responsible for running non-filtered shell commands.

Such a provider could be implemented as a python plugin for example, using a newly spawned window/buffer as a terminal emulator. Since there are many ready to use terminal emulation libraries for python, the plugin part should be relatively easy to accomplish. Though I'm still not sure if we have a way to redirect every keypress in a buffer/window to a user function.

On November 19, 2014 11:43:57 PM EAT, Thiago de Arruda notifications@github.com wrote:

> > I also think a solution for this should be looked for, if possible.
> > It's not a big deal, specially taking into account what is given in
> > exchange. But it will for sure annoy many people, cause it will break
> > their habits. So, if something can be done, we should strive for it.
> 
> A possible solution crossed by mind: A "bang command provider", which
> would be responsible for running non-filtered shell commands.
> 
> Such a provider could be implemented as a python plugin for example,
> using a newly spawned window/buffer as a terminal emulator. Since there
> are many ready to use terminal emulation libraries for python, the
> plugin part should be relatively easy to accomplish. Though I'm still
> not sure if we have a way to redirect every keypress in a buffer/window
> to a user function.
> 
> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1496#issuecomment-63709975

You may want to check out how GVim copes with this problem for any insights. Also getchar(): both take all of the input. Though I think just CTRL-D and CTRL-C mappings and InsertCharPre event are enough, so I would not be sure that you _need_ to redirect every keypress.

> A possible solution crossed by mind: A "bang command provider"

I don't like it. Old behaviour: vim stops rendering the screen and lets the process take over stdin/out. Provider behaviour with UI: UI captures input and sends it to nvim through feedkeys, we forward it to the bang provider, it produces some output and sends it to us, we forward it to the UI in a way it'll understand. Seems like a lot of back-and-forth, especially if the UI implements the bang provider (which would be a smart move, IMO).

But it's easy to criticise; I can't think of a better solution.

> You may want to check out how GVim copes with this problem for any insights.

I've already seen it: It spawns a PTY on supported systems, though as `:h gui-pty` explains, the feature is incomplete and not portable(also reason why I choose not to maintain this on Nvim)

>  Also getchar(): both take all of the input. Though I think just CTRL-D and CTRL-C mappings and InsertCharPre event are enough, so I would not be sure that you _need_ to redirect every keypress.

Allowing the user receive every keypress would mean user-defined modes are possible, which would be more powerful for implementing something as complex as a terminal emulators(or any program that runs with a buffer as UI). I will have a look at implementing this later.

> I don't like it. Old behaviour: vim stops rendering the screen and lets the process take over stdin/out. Provider behaviour with UI: UI captures input and sends it to nvim through feedkeys, we forward it to the bang provider, it produces some output and sends it to us, we forward it to the UI in a way it'll understand. Seems like a lot of back-and-forth, especially if the UI implements the bang provider (which would be a smart move, IMO).
> 
> But it's easy to criticise; I can't think of a better solution.

While there's a lot more processing than with direct pty inheritance, the delay may not be so visible to the user, especially an implementation that buffers output and only displays to the user with a minimal time interval
Will #2076 fix this?

@elmart no but it will offer an alternative: `:term git add -p`. The downside is that plugins relying on spawning interactive programs will have to be adapted for neovim. Fortunately there doesn't seem to be many such plugins out there, probably a consequence of the unreliability when running gvim.

At first I considered reimplementing bang commands on top of the feature introduced in #2076 but came to conclusion that would be compromising too much just for compatiblity. See [this](https://github.com/junegunn/fzf/issues/137#issuecomment-77713710) for an explanation.

> no but it will offer an alternative: `:term git add -p`.

vim-fugitive did so in https://github.com/tpope/vim-fugitive/pull/624.
What is the suggested workaround for launching an interactive :! command in cmdline mode?
Use `:te` instead.

As far as I understand, :terminal is not allowed from cmdline mode, which is why I asked.

``` vim
fun! Test()
  :term echo "Test!"
endfun
cnoremap <silent> <c-n> <c-\>eTest()<cr>
```

gives me `E523: Not allowed here: :enew | call termopen("echo \"Test!\"") | startinsert`
Looks like a bug. ~~We may need to shellescape?~~ `E523` is for "secure" mode. Not sure why that would trigger in command-line.

@justinmk Because this is not true command mode. `<C-\>e` is used to edit the command-line and allowing `:term` (or any command that does something with buffers) is not a good idea. I would not be surprised to hear that it has technical reason behind this. My usual workaround for such kind of things is messing with `feedkeys()`.
Reopening this to track this new use-case.

Fwiw I think it's very useful to be able to be able to call external programs and use their output in `cmdline`. I agree commands dealing with buffers should probably be disallowed in cmdline mode, but the issue here is that the behaviour of :! has been changed with regards to vim, and :term is the replacement for interactive commands. So in this case we've actually lost integration with the host system rather than gained some, which as far as I understand is one of the main project goals of neovim.
@ggVGc By "new use case" I mean "new information that was not previously written down".

@ggVGc `system()` should still be working. `!` has nothing to do with “using output in cmdline”. I have actually no idea why would `!` be useful in `<C-\>e` expression or `<expr>` mapping: I would never imagine that calling _any_ interactive program _in this context_ has any sense except for making me angry and for other programs `system()` should be fine. (Though mostly because this is hard context switching (altscreen gets replaced with regular screen), if I need to e.g. output commit hash to the command-line I have nothing againts using `input()` in a mapping.)
@ggVGc Does `input()` and `system()` cover your use-case? (Of course `system()` is also not interactive)

> So in this case we've actually lost integration with the host system rather than gained some, which as far as I understand is one of the main project goals of neovim.

`termopen()` lets you integrate nvim with interactive programs, have you seen fzf? While we diverged the behavior of `system()` and `!`, it was for allowing the full client server architecture planned from the beginning of the project. We can't have UIs running in different processes and have programs require nvim stdio inheritance in order to display output.

Also, its not like vim behavior is consistent anyway, gvim also has limited support for interactive programs in `!` and `system()`(which is why plugins like fzf and selecta dont work in gvim).

I hope we'll eventually be able to run full interactive programs with `!` and `system()`, this should be possible by making some enhancements to the terminal module and have it draw directly to the screen(instead of a buffer), but it is not a primary goal.

Yeah, I get it, and I'm not arguing the tradeoffs. Just pointing out that something that's previously worked(and I think has been very useful), for now doesn't in nvim. But I understand the community already knows about this. Fzf is actually what my use case was, I have been using fzf to bring up a fuzzy list of completions in `cmdline` mode. So, i.e :e <c-n> would give me a fuzzy list of all files in the current cwd to open, or :h f<c-n> gives me a list of all help entries starting with f.
there are some open issues in terminal that affect fzf. for example, junegunn/fzf#426

If there is no support for interactive commands, then how about some ways to control main terminal?
I understand, we currently have env variables to enable cursor shapes and already integrated Focus\* events not long ago. But for `urxvt`, which has no focus support, I need enable/disable focus events manually, by sending escape sequence `"\e]777;focus;on\x7"` to corresponding custom urxvt extension ([vim-focus-autocmd](https://github.com/amerlyq/vim-focus-autocmd) + [urxvt-ext-evolved](https://github.com/amerlyq/urxvt-ext-evolved)). 

Therefore, as `t_ti/t_te` don't work now, I could use `silent !echo -e "\e]777;focus;on\x7"` instead. But it don't work anymore. How could I send this escape sequence to main terminal?
It is planned.

I would be interesting if you have implemented the previous vim behavior of ":shell" in Neovim, with a new command like :lshell (Legacy Shell, for example).

I prefer to start programs outside Neovim, especially because :terminal is sometimes buggy. :terminal closes the file I am currently editing unexpectedly. Especially when I run Python 3 programs. This bug didn't happen every time I used :terminal, so I don't know exactly why causes it.
How I wish this part of Thiago's comment was real: "I'm starting to think it's better to find a solution to that soon."

Tmux users may find this mapping useful:

```
if has('nvim')
  cnoremap <expr> ! strlen(getcmdline())?'!':('!tmux split-window -c '.getcwd().' ')
endif
```
He, nice one :D

~~This is a terrible design decision!~~ There should be a way to run a command in the full underlying shell without quitting or suspending nvim. This breaks just so many workflows, as all the bug reports referencing this issue show. Personally, I've always done `!less %` for getting a quick view of the current file for copy/paste in the terminal without disrupting my vim layout. This now is no longer possible (I'd now have do `Ctrl-z`, `less <filename>`, `fg`). If you're going to change the behavior of `!`, at least provide some different mechanism to achieve the old behavior, so I can create a custom mapping!

Edit: @phodge's workaround solves my problem for now. But still, while I understand the reasoning behind the new behavior of `!`, you should be extremely wary of any user-facing change that'll break compatibility with terminal-vim, and provide an easy work-around if you have to.

@goerz There is `:terminal` for the task currently, as mentioned some comments above and in some other issues. There is some desire to implement the equivalent for Vim’s `guioptions+=!`, but this time Bram managed to beat us and I am not sure whether somebody is working on that. @justinmk should know better.

If https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5541, respectively https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5431 was implemented, that would also allow for a workaround for the problem of opening an interactive process using the full width of the terminal, without disrupting any window layouts in vim. I would be able to do

    :tab te less %

https://github.com/janlazo/dotvim8/blob/master/autoload/dotvim8.vim#L79-L124 is my backward-compatible workaround for `:!` via `:terminal` which I use in a [batchfile](https://github.com/janlazo/dotvim8/blob/master/after/ftplugin/dosbatch.vim) or [powershell script](https://github.com/janlazo/dotvim8/blob/master/after/ftplugin/ps1.vim) for `K`.

It's a shim but I'm satisfied with it and I don't use `set guioptions+=!` in GVim.

I extracted my workaround and put it in a separate repo, https://github.com/janlazo/vim-bang-terminal.
Feedback is appreciated.
Is there any news? Got an issue from fugitive [github.com/tpope/vim-fugitive/issues/1125](https://github.com/tpope/vim-fugitive/issues/1125)

Yeah, this is a deal breaker.
As a new user who was excited about nvim, I'm forced into dropping it until this is dealt with.  NeoVim is not a vim replacement without implementing the current features; and this is not esoteric. This is pretty fundamental vim functionality, and pretty common among programs that implement vim-like interfaces.
Rather than close all the issues, this should be considered a critical bug and resolved (now 5 years after the original complaint and still going strong).

> Rather than close all the issues, this should be considered a critical bug and resolved (now 5 years after the original complaint and still going strong).

But this issue is open. Only duplicate issues are closed.

> Rather than close all the issues, this should be considered a critical bug and resolved (now 5 years after the original complaint and still going strong).

It is planned to be fixed in 0.5, see #10842 . Note that gvim did not support this until 1-2 years ago, I don't think one would consider gvim to be lacking "fundamental vim functionality" until then.

@josephholsten I'm using Neovim for more than 3 years, I spend something like 6 hours each day in Neovim and trust me it's not a big/medium/small deal at all, nothing relies on this, I have more than 150 plugins and I never noticed this issue past 3 years. I'm subscribed to this issue because in the beginning it was super weird for me that this issue exist on Neovim and I thought I can't use Neovim until it's solved, so I subscribed to this issue but in next few hours I found out how to update my vimrc (`init.vim`) and then I forgot this issue even exist. I don't remember the changes I had to do, but I remember it didn't take more than few hours.

Please feel free to list the things that are affected by this issue and are annoying you and we'll try to provide you solutions.
@sassanh I suspect you meant someone else ;-)

> > Rather than close all the issues, this should be considered a critical bug and resolved (now 5 years after the original complaint and still going strong).
> 
> But this issue is open. Only duplicate issues are closed.
> 
> > Rather than close all the issues, this should be considered a critical bug and resolved (now 5 years after the original complaint and still going strong).
> 
> It is planned to be fixed in 0.5, see #10842 . Note that gvim did not support this until 1-2 years ago, I don't think one would consider gvim to be lacking "fundamental vim functionality" until then.

Arrogant fucking programmers...

Ok, what-the-fuck ever. Do as you will. I’ll keep using real vim.

While I don't sympathize with Joshua's conclusion, this problem did surprise me when I first encountered it. It's by no means a deal-breaker, but I wouldn't say it's a non-issue either. Particularly, I miss `:w !sudo tee %` mentioned in #1716, but I installed the suda.vim plugin and moved on.

Trust me, many of us want this fixed. We spent our time-units on other things which also needed to be done. Since we only had X time-units and we used them up on the other things, this thing didn't get done yet. Meanwhile, anyone is welcome to start working on it.

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: :! (bang) and system() are not interactive
